Summary: How to Find and Deal with Edge Cases in #UXdesign?#Edgecases are scenarios that deviate from the happy path and are mistakenly considered very rare and unlikely to happen. Thus edge cases are written off because of this. However, dismissing these edge cases could also be dismissing how marginalized groups may interact with the solution, putting a group of users’ needs over others. There's a list of main questions #ConversationDesigner can use to handle edge cases:⠀⠀ How are we making this decision? Based on the timeline? Resources? Business needs? User evidence? ⠀⠀ What end-users are we ignoring? ⠀⠀ Do we have data to back up each edge case? If not, we’re making an assumption. If yes, then why is this an edge case? ⠀⠀ Who and where did we collect the data from?Solving edge cases is important from two perspectives. In the first place, from the perspective of the user, but also from the perspective of the code. You should remember that edge cases that are not addressed can negatively affect the #userexperience.For more read our full article ⇨ http://masterofcode.com/.../ethics-in-conversation-design...#UX #uxdesign #uxuidesign #conversationalai #conversationdesign #customerexperience #CX

Summary: Here are some top tips on how to craft great #conversational #experiences in both voice and chat channels. Amanda Stevens, our Director of Conversation Design shared some top tips when designing for voice:⠀⠀  Use contextual dialogues that align with the bot’s channel it lives on. For example, use words like ‘see’, ‘view’, and ‘chat’ in chat channels, and more audio-based terms such as ‘hear’, ‘listen’, ‘talk, in voice channels. ⠀⠀  Ensure you have shorter, more succinct dialogues in voice experiences compared to #chatbots, so users can absorb and consume content without needing to ask for dialogs to be repeated.  ⠀⠀  As voice assistants take a little bit longer to process user inputs or connect to APIs compared to chat experiences, set user expectations for those longer delays. Summary: Read these useful #TIPS shared by our #CxD expert John Mowat, as a response to the question “What do you think are the most sensitive aspects a conversation designer should consider in order to avoid key biased issues?"      It's how you gather feedback from your stakeholders. If you say something like, in warning, a question to the stakeholders on our project, should we use this emoji, you've already implied that you should have emojis in the project and maybe that's not the right tone or presentation for that brand.      The second thing is bias in things like accessibility or cultural differences, sexism, and racism, and how do those creep into the design and into the end result that we deliver. Don't ever use real people as your characters for a user persona, come up with cartoon characters, or have somebody commissioned artwork for it or something like this.      One of the most important things is just bringing awareness to that which #conversations like this one, and all of the literature that's been generated helps with focus groups can identify that during design, if you run early designs, and early dialog, copy past focus groups, and ask them to flag things that made them feel uncomfortable, hurt their feelings or anything like this, it can really help to identify those things.Keep your eyes open for more tips in the weeks to come as our experts get ready to share more #ConversationDesign insights.#conversationdesigntips #UX #conversationalAI #AI #artificialintelligence
